column1: == Geology ==
The prominent granite dome is visible for many miles in the surrounding basin of the Llano Uplift. The weathered dome
column2: standing above the surrounding plain is known to geologists as a monadnock. The rock is actually the visible above-ground part of a segmented ridge
column3: the surface expression of a large igneous batholith
column4: called the Town Mountain Granite of middle Precambrian (1
column5: 082 ± 6 million years ago) material that intruded into earlier metamorphic schist
column6: called the Packsaddle Schist. The intrusive granite of the rock mass
column8: was exposed by extensive erosion of the surrounding sedimentary rock
column10: which is exposed a few miles to the south of Enchanted Rock.

column1: == Legends ==
Folklore of local Tonkawa
column2: Apache and Comanche tribes ascribes magical and spiritual powers to the rock (hence the name 'Enchanted Rock'). While attempting to hide from Anglo settlers in the area
column3: the natives would hide on the top two tiers of the rock
column4: where they were invisible from the ground below. The first European to visit the area was probably Álvar Núñez Cabeza de Vaca in 1536. The Tonkawa
column5: who inhabited the area in the 16th century
column6: believed that ghost fires flickered at the top of the dome. In particular they heard unexplained creaking and groaning
column7: which geologists attribute to the rock's night-time contraction after being heated by the sun during the day. The name "Enchanted Rock" derives from Spanish and Anglo-Texan interpretations of such legends and related folklore; the name "Crying Rock" has also been given to the formation.
